p: We found that, in the early 20 th century, circumcision patterns in Central and West Africa exhibited much stronger regional differences than nowadays. Peoples of the Adamawa-Ubangi linguistic cluster (occupying most CAR and northern DRC), and many Bantu peoples of the Orientale and Équateur provinces of DRC, adopted it in late 19 th–early 20 th century [95]. In Rwanda and Burundi, circumcision was not practiced, a pattern that persists today [95], [96] ( Text S2). In West Africa, most ethnic groups were circumcised, with some exceptions (e.g., the Akan peoples from eastern Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana, and many Gur peoples from northeastern Côte d'Ivoire, Burkina-Faso, and Ghana) ( Text S2).
